data.title: First Love: The Litter on the Breeze (1997)
data.meta_description: Faced with the task of creating a film about first love for his producer Wong Kar-wai, Kot ruminates on his creative process, his rejected ideas, and finally his two chosen tales, about a sleepwalker guided through the night by a lonely admirer, and a married convenience store owner faced with the vengeful first love that he once rejected.
data.text:
Just because you pretty much acknowledge onscreen that your film is a mess does not in anyway justify it being a mess. First Love: The Litter on the Breeze is an experimental, offbeat attempt to create a film similar to Wong Kar-wai's Chungking Express and Fallen Angels. It has the same director of photography, Wong as a producer, and the same type of quirky, dual love stories.

However, unlike those masterpieces, director Eric Kot strives to make entire sections of his film unwatchable. Kot embraces fourth-wall breaking thoroughly, with constant breaks in the story to allow footage of himself or his voiceover to explain behind the scenes information. This Brechtian approach, which I am usually fond of, just doesn't work here as Kot's…

Oh my God where do I begin.

It’s funny because it’s pretentious. It’s moving because it’s authentic. When you’re about to take it seriously, you’re about to crack. Then while you’re laughing, with tears of joy, there would be a moment you look at the scene and think to yourself, woahhh what a great scene, what a nice setup, what an unforgettable frame. And I was constantly blown away by the editing.

It is like a parody to Wong Kar Wai’s film?! Yet it has so much heart and does not fail to touch me personally. Bold stories but the romance does not fail. What a sweet and smart idea to put a sleep walker and a garbage man, falling…
